customize.text: Cendre Nehri

Fontaine'in kentsel alanları büyüdükçe, düzenin ışığı gölgeleri uzaklaştırdı ve kanalizasyonlar sonunda Fleuve Cendre'ye dönüştü. Düzeni sağlamak zor olduğundan, Eduardo Baker ve arkadaşları lağımlarda iktidarı ele geçirdi. Fleuve Cendre “yurttaşları” arasındaki anlaşmazlıkları çözmeye, yeni evlenenleri kutsamaya ve tüccarları çeteler tarafından gasp edilmekten, taciz edilmekten ve şantaja uğramaktan korumaya başladılar. Fontaine Sarayı yetkilileri Fleuve Cendre'yi tasfiye etmeye karar verdiğinde Baker tutuklandı ve çöle sürüldü. Sürgüne giderken, yandaşlarının yardımıyla Poisson'a kaçtı ve hem şehrin kendisini hem de Baker'i taşıyan Maison Gardiennage üyelerini rehin aldı. Çok sayıda mantıksız talepte bulununca Emanuel Guillotin yönetimindeki Marechaussee Avcıları olaya müdahale etti. Bu çatışma Baker ve Poisson Belediye Başkanı da dahil olmak üzere çok sayıda kişinin ölümüyle sonuçlandı. Fleuve Cendre halkı, şehrin altında ne yağmuru ne de güneşi olan bir şehirde yaşıyor olsalar da, işçilerin bol çalışkanlığı ve azminin onlara zaman zaman yüzeyde yaşama hakkı kazandırdığına, bazen de yeraltındaki sulu diyarlarını en az yukarıdaki dünya kadar güzel bir meskene dönüştürdüğüne inanıyordu. Fleuve Cendre'nin tasfiyesinden sonra, bu yeraltı şehrini inşa etmek için kullanılan bazı aletler silah olarak kullanılabilecekleri için yasaklandı.

Fleuve Cendre düşman güçlerin yaşadığı oldukça tehlikeli bir yer olarak kabul edilir, ancak Spina di Rosula artık burayı gözetmektedir. Önceleri örgüt her şeyi karşılayabiliyordu, ancak eski başkan Callas'ın cinayetle suçlanması ve ardından adli bir düelloda öldürülmesinin ardından Spina di Rosula nakit sıkıntısı çekmeye başladı. Artık operasyonlarının çoğunu Fleuve Cendre'deki merkezlerinde yürütüyorlar. Örgüt yasadışı ya da etik olmayan yollardan kazanç elde edilmesine izin vermediğinden, şu anda Fontaine sakinlerinin destekleriyle ayakta durmaktadır. Fleuve Cendre'de örgüt üyeleri Sonny ve Luca, barmen Tetreaux ve Spina di Rosula'nın danışmanı olan bir çadır kaplumbağası olan Consigliere bulunabilir. Ayrıca, bir tüccar Crossa da orada bulunmaktadır.

When the officer of the law and father of young Chevreuse, the future captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, was accused of leaking classified information, her family moved to the Fleuve Cendre. The girl's mother grew more and more tired every day, worrying for her husband. To take care of her mother, Chevreuse didn't hesitate to take up burdens that one as young as she should never have had to shoulder, stepping into the dark currents that swirled through the Fleuve Cendre. Perhaps it was because the residents of the Fleuve Cendre had heard tell of or been on the receiving end of her upright father's care that so many helping hands were extended to her. A well-meaning shop owner gave her a job, and the couple next door often took care of her infirm mother. And when the children of the Fleuve Cendre heard that the child of a Garde had come to live among them, they flocked to her like plaintiffs and defendants, seeking her arbitration on all manner of quarrels and disputes. <color=#ffffffd9>"Chevreuse! You gotta uphold justice, y'know!"</color> So cried the children with one voice, before laughing as one. They did not truly intend to allow Chevreuse to determine who was at fault but rather saw it all as merely another game. Yet the next day, Chevreuse brought a thick stack of legal materials when she went to see them, along with a notebook newly opened to the first page and began speaking to the chortling children in a tone most serious. <color=#ffffffd9>"Very well. Let both sides present their evidence."</color> And from that day forward, the Fleuve Cendre had one more enforcer of the law — the littlest one around. But unlike the law enforcement officers aboveground, all judgments rendered by Chevreuse were executed under her personal supervision. There in the sewers, she learned many ways to ensure that "justice" would be upheld.
When a series of murders inspired by "The Two Musketeers" occurred during the Fontinalia Festival in Fontaine, the investigation led Chevreuse to the Fleuve Cendre. Shortly before this, one of the tavern visitors got drunk at dinner and lost his weapon, but three days later it turned up in the corner without the slightest sign of wear. In addition, residents woke up at night to the sound of gunfire. In a remote part of the sewer, Chevreuse found broken boards and several broken bottles. The criminal tried to clean up, but there were clear traces of bullets on the wall. The captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol assumed that someone had taken the weapon, brought it home, and returned it after disassembling it and examining its design. A few weeks later they built their own musket and brought it to the Fleuve Cendre to practice shooting. A few days later, they found their target, committed a crime, and left a rainbow rose on his body, just like in the novel. The victim lived in the Fleuve Cendre. It later turned out that the killer was the sister of the author of the novel, whose mother was killed by a rich man who was trying to hide their relationship. The famous book was based on the siblings' real childhood. The deceased was an assassin sent by their father.
In the Fleuve Cendre, a Fatui agent,
suspected of kidnapping Sir Arthur, met with informants. It was he who told Editor Jenck about the secret laboratory of the researcher who created the intelligent lie detector and about the connection with The Steambird. He helped the newspaper expose the fraud of the Elegant Tableware Confrerie in the hope of obtaining inside information from the publication, but Jenck had nothing to repay him with. Then Baulard decided to enter the newspaper building and get information himself but only discovered the disappearance of Sir Arthur and a letter threatening the editors.

More than 500 years ago, two young thieving sisters who made their living cheating and stealing grew up in the Fleuve Cendre. One day they were at the opera house and saw a comedy by Master Coppelius about an elusive thief who was a master of appearing and disappearing at their leisure. What is called magic is quite similar to fraud and theft. The first relies on acting and narrative creation, and the second relies on technique. The sisters had an idea of relying on their skills and technique to step onto the stage, under the shining lights, of using their brilliant performances to illuminate equally the dreams of those forced to stand, as well as those seated in luxurious VIP boxes. One of them would play "Parsifal," the other, her assistant Josephine. Their first performances were in Eduardo's taverns, beside the sewers, and in front of food stalls, from being before the eyes of children, brightly shining out from beneath faces stained with ash and oil and amidst the applause of the denizens. Subsequently, they were replaced by the bright spotlights of the splendorous theater, brilliant, burning like the sun. Just as the light of their performances illuminated both the luxurious VIP booths and the standing audience, the name "Parsifal" became the talk of the town in the cities, both above and below.
During the Fleuve Cendre operation, the girl who always played Josephine rushed back home. All the people knew Parsifal, but an assistant is merely an assistant. But just as the assistant on stage is lopped in two by the sword, yet never harmed, and the missing pocket watch always returns to the audience unseen, the girl finally lost her "place" in life. And thus, she designed a "grand magic trick" that belonged to them.

<color=#ffffffd9>"It is I, the masterful magician — Parsifal 'the Great'!"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"You will bear witness to a fantastic world, never before imagined!"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Here there shall be no aristocrats, no kings — no swords shall be pointed at you!"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"None shall be born into wealth, none into poverty inescapable!"</color>

Parsifal was present at the siege of Poisson. Later, the great illusionist (or Josephine, posing as Parsifal), due to an "unexpected transgression," demanded a trial by combat, and her opponent was the Champion Duelist Marfisa. In the Court of Fontaine, everyone discussed whether Marfisa's origin would disrupt either her judgment or performance during the duel, what of her past connection to Parsifal, and which of them was the stronger fighter. For Parsifal, this battle turned out to be the last. Marfisa grew up in the Fleuve Cendre and for as little as a slice or two of moldy bread, she would not flinch from pulling out a rusty blade to take the life of someone as insignificant as herself. She thought that everything up to this point seemed utterly meaningless, with nothing achieved and nothing to hope for. However, in spite of her expectations, death did not come. Once, she opened her eyes and saw a girl (most likely, Parsifal) smiling back gently, who then placed a flower behind her ear.

<color=#ffffffd9>"We call this flower a Lumidouce Bell, which in the language of flowers... means hope. Look, the color matches your hair."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"You have such beautiful eyes. It would be such a pity if all they reflected was despair."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Come, little lass with the sapphire eyes, let me trade this flower for your heart."</color>

Thus did Marfisa, who would be later famed as a Champion Duelist, first step into the city above ground. Watching on from the luxury of a VIP box in the magnificent theater, she could no longer remember the smiling faces of the magician and their assistant on stage, only how, as the fantasy played out, a profusion of flowers blossomed under the dazzling spotlight — bright, pure, and ever so strong. She understood that she should yet cherish hope — that this life, having now seen the light, might blossom like Lumidouce. Marfisa started copying all spear-fighting techniques she had ever seen and found expression in her performance. It seemed like she was dancing with "death" itself on a stage. Once she fought with a young swordsman and the Marechaussee Hunter, Emanuel Guillotin. She was bewildered by his crafty eyes, and deceived by his intentionally slow rhythm, she finally revealed a critical weakness that she normally never would, and her arm was struck by his blade, forcing her to concede that her spearmanship was inferior. He suggested changing her approach and making "that which is immutable" and "justice" her "rule."

<color=#ffffffd9>"What right do you surface dwellers have to speak of justice? Your skills may be slightly superior to mine, yet you need not lecture me so, all high and mighty."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Sooner or later, Hunter, there will come a day when you too will fall before my lance."</color>

Despite her reply, Guillotin was right, and she became guided by justice, and offered up a cold elegy to those who would seek to evade judgment. She became a purple-clad enforcer instead, upholding justice "as it ought to be," until the fire of Poisson brought the criminal Parsifal before her. Marfisa wanted to seek Guillotin and give it her all in a final duel, but he had long retired after what happened in Poisson. People said he hid his face beneath a mask and turned to strong drink, but the spear-wielder had to discover the truth behind the rumors for herself. After following the trail to the mask left behind by the swordsman, all her trials and tribulations seemed to have been rewarded at last. However, the end of that pursuit was most unexpected and had nothing to do with the justice sought by the once-legendary Champion Duelist. Like Emanuel Guillotin, Marfisa was dissolved by the Narzissenkreuz Ordo's members. When she fell into those pure sourcewaters, all that had previously seemed self-evident lost its meaning. Up to the moment her memories dissolved in the water, she never knew that the Lumidouce Bell's true meaning in the language of flowers was never hope. And at the end of that long pursuit, even fate did not offer her the blossoming elegy that it ought to have.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Ah, the renowned Marfisa this time, is it...?"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Take heart. Your fine spear-arm will be of use."</color>

During the time of Eduardo Baker, the eldest daughter Leticia grew up in the Randolph family of aristocrats. She was taught to maintain her noble bearing and purity of appearance, and not to show her emotions. Leticia's heart hankered after the adventure, so secretly from everyone, she changed clothes and went down to the Fleuve Cendre. She just wanted to see the lives of those base folk who had no control over their destinies. For her, this was even more interesting than Parsifal's magic. The reality was not what Leticia was prepared for, and when perils unseen — like music, lies, or poisoned wine — were about to be unsheathed and show their keen edge, she met one of her father's subordinates, Reed. He recognized her by the absence of traces of machine oil and blood on her clothes. And from her gait, it was easy to guess that she didn't often have to wear pants. Leticia fell in love with Reed and stayed with him in the Fleuve Cendre, taking the name of the rose. When she met her father many years later, he still hoped that she would return home with her child, and the Randolphs were willing to use "some Randolph magic" for her husband. In fact, her whole life was a lie. When Reed saw her in the Fleuve Cendre, he considered her a trophy that could not be missed up to enter the greatest of houses, the Randolphs. When Leticia remained in the underground city years later, his ephemeral hope had now vanished like smoke. He asked her to leave this place for the sake of the children's lives:

<color=#ffffffd9>"Dear Leticia, think of the children, of those newly sprouted trees,"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Surely they should not be born amidst cannon fire, or grow up amidst the mud and filthy waters."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Are we to nurture them with wrathful tears and hateful oaths?"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Shall we leave them to inherit confused dreams or a mission with its outlook yet unknown?"</color>

But she only replied that their future had been arranged and would be assured. Later,
with her child and husband was captured in a photograph taken during the siege of Poisson.

In the Fleuve Cendre, the workshop of Cesar, a magician and teacher of Lyney and Lynette, is situated. In addition, Uther's clothing factory is located there. When Chiori first arrived in Fontaine, she and Uther were aspiring fashion designers who dreamed of attracting the attention of the fashion world, so for some time they worked together towards a common goal. At first, they both wanted to break tradition and make unusual clothes that would bring sighs of regret into the lobby. But with every new negative feedback from clients, with every new rejection, Uther's confidence was fading. In the end, just before Fashion Week, he decided that they could not bring to life the ideas they had always dreamed of, and that was the end of their collaboration. Chiori then put everything she had on the line and gave it her all, and on the last day, she put together a collection that she was pleased with, presenting it at the show.

As a result, she received recognition and glory, and Uther has tried every year since then to destroy her business. When he falsely accused her of being associated with criminals and the poor quality of her materials, Chiori decided to take a two-pronged approach and face off against Uther at a fashion show and then attack his reputation. When Uther's factory was closed before the Fashion Show, she, along with the Traveler and Paimon went to the Fleuve Cendre. Since the factory was always open to visitors, they calmly walked inside and found that the production itself was in the dirt. After collecting the necessary evidence, they found themselves in a trap set by Uther. Taking over Uther, Chiori sent the Traveler and Paimon with photos to the Fashion Show. The Steambird journalist, Charlotte, used the photographs they obtained to write an exposing article, and the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Chevreuse, arrested Uther.

customize.text: Marcotte Station

Marcotte Station is the terminus of the Navia aquabus line, connecting Erinnyes and the Court of Fontaine. Several fountains are installed at the station, and one of them has a lion statue. If three teardrop keys are brought to this fountain, a passage leading to the roots of the Weeping Willow, the main information center of Erinnyes, will open.

One day, a guy named Remaudiere was babysitting his sister Keratry while their parents went to the opera house. When they were walking outside, Remaudiere decided to show her a trick and "make" the fountain stop in order to take his sister home. In fact, he simply waited for the fountain to stop working, but the next day he discovered that the fountain was still not working. Remaudiere was afraid that his sister would tell his parents about his "magic," so he asked the fountain manager to fix the problem, but the fountain never worked. The Traveler and Paimon came to his aid, getting all the necessary parts to fix the fountain before the guy got into trouble.
One day at the station, the Traveler and Paimon encountered a strange, panicked woman who thought someone was trying to harm her. After calming her down, the Traveler and Paimon learned that the woman, Guijarro, was a writer who had been overthinking her detective novel to the point of becoming paranoid. She wanted to take the aquabus to the Court of Fontaine to get coffee, but she immediately imagined the many ways she could be killed on the aquabus and was unable to even board. When the Traveler escorted her to the Café Lutece, Guijarro became nervous that the coffee might be poisoned. When the owner of the café, Arouet, threatened to throw her out if she continued to scare his customers, she apologetically bought three more cups of coffee. After finishing her detective novel, Guijarro set off for Qiaoying Village in the Chenyu Vale.

Yeşim taşının hafif kokusu ve kadim şarkısı, Qiaoying Köyü'nü geçerek nehirler boyunca Yilong İskelesi'nin hareketli limanına doğru birlikte sürüklenir. Güneyin sisle örtülü tepeleri arasında gizlenmiş ne maceralar ve talihler bekliyor...?

customize.text: Fountain of Lucine

The Fountain of Lucine is the place where all the water flowing through Fontaine converges, so people like to make wishes here. The origin of throwing coins into the fountain comes from tossing Hydro Sigils into the Fountain of Lucine, which is in fact the correct way of making a wish to the fountain. To this day, newlyweds in love throw coins into the Fountain of Lucine, wishing for peaceful and happy lives.
All Fontainians were Oceanids once, who, according to a legend, emerged from the tear of the first Hydro Archon, Egeria. The increase in the number of the Oceanids did not require any pairing off or matchmaking. After gaining sufficient understanding and emotion, they approached the Hydro Archon or an elder for permission to "reproduce," which resulted in their division into little Oceanids. Some believed their "reproduction" served as a permit, granting permission for the dreams and desires within Oceanids to be bestowed with a new name — much like the names of childhood dreams throughout the ages. After some Oceanids became humans, they forgot about their origin. They still asked permission to "reproduce," but it was considered a symbolic act. They threw coins into the Fountain of Lucine wishing for the children, and then their wishes were granted. People believed that the spirits in the water would bless them with healthy and happy children. When Neuvillette turned the Fontainians into ordinary people, they were able to reproduce like all other inhabitants of Teyvat.

People's tears contain the most vivid emotions: tears of absolute happiness, fear, and grief. The Fountain of Lucine is a place where water from all over Fontaine flows, so even tears that fall to the ground end up here. People who are highly sensitive to the Hydro element are able to hear these emotions contained in someone's tears. Thus, the Traveler could hear Furina's tears, struggling over Fontaine's prophecy. In addition, one day they drank the water of the Primordial Sea, which increased sensitivity, and heard the voice of a mysterious Oceanid calling Vacher. This Oceanid asked Vacher not to search for Vigneire, an adventurer who was dissolved by the water of the Primordial Sea, anymore. Vacher was her beloved once, and after losing Vigneire, he began to dissolve other women in an attempt to return his beloved out of grief. When Vacher finally found Vigneire many years later, she didn't even want to talk to him. The consciousness of all the women he had dissolved over 20 years attacked him, and Vacher died of great fright.

To the right of the fountain, a scene with the Icewind Suite is located. According to the original plan of Mr. Bossuet, a senior technician of the Fontaine Research Institute, Coppelius and Coppelia were clockwork meka dedicated to the art of dance. After Bossuet's retirement, Maillardet took over the project. He understood the concepts of "mechanics" and "dance" in his own way, so as generations passed, the functions of the "mechanical dancers" were improved, but gradually moved away from Bossuet's original design. Pneumousia was added, making them not only good at dancing but also highly capable fighters. Two different combat modes for Coppelius and Coppelia were created based on the differences between Pneuma and Ousia, Nemesis of Coppelius, and Dirge of Coppelia.

Mechanical dancers can perform many plays. For example, one is about how Coppelius lost the battle with temptation and was punished for it, about how Coppelia falls in love, but unrequitedly, and therefore almost dies. Or how Coppelia goes on a journey to rescue Coppelius from captivity. The script of "Clockwork Coppelia" was never published, but some people have collected and organized all the records to reconstruct part of the intent of Coppelius's work. One such story tells how Coppelius's plan was exposed before the Marechaussee Hunters, and how he said his final farewells to Coppelia before his punishment. Coppelius asks Coppelia to sing for him one last time.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Wind a thread about my heart, and with it, bind me tightly! Lock me up in chains and fetters, and let me be destroyed in your eyes.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>For mine heart is decided, from today forth, I shall not seek those that make me happy, but bring happiness to those I choose."</color>

Another play tells how Coppelia confesses the purpose of her journey to the youth traveling with her and resolves to follow her creator, who in her eyes, has already passed on. She believes that when her rusted gears return to the same ash as Coppelius's bones, all sin will be forgotten.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Never again need I see the sun, moon, or stars, never again need I hear the birds singing joyously in the forests, never again need I force this lonely heart of mine to continue beating on in a world that is already bereft of he who bestowed it upon me."</color>

Ms. Qiu and her film crew can be seen near the fountain. They all come from Qiaoying Village, which is famous for its tea. Due to the high competition in the tea business, they decided to take up filming commercials for the village's tea merchants. The group made a lot of Mora from these films, but soon there were other skilled people in the village whose films featured real opera singers. So, Ms. Qiu and the others came to Fontaine to get advice from experts in filmmaking. Here they met Geisert, a master of using light and shadow to convey a narrative. His films have not yet gained much popularity in Fontaine, but they interested Ms. Qiu. While filming their film, the crew lost their camera and later dropped the film with the footage in the water. Thanks to the help of the Traveler, all the footage was returned. Later, Ms. Qiu and her team returned to Qiaoying Village to continue filming.

customize.text: Opera Epiclese

The Opera Epiclese is the most magnificent building on Erinnyes. When the Fontainians speak of the "opera house," that's what they are normally referring to. The opera house has another, more important role, besides serving as a site for various cultural performances. It is also a courtroom in which all cases in Fontaine are judged. Ever since the first diluvian period, the Opera Epiclese has stood atop the consecrated Island of Erinnyes. Overlooking the city above the waters, it symbolizes the new era's commitment to the rule of law and the pursuit of justice. The true and the fantastical, the comedic and tragic find a stage here equally. An ancient Fontainian playwright once said: <color=#ffffffd9>"All the world's a stage, and all us merely players."</color>

Huge scales called the Oratrice Mecanique d'Analyse Cardinale stand on the stage of the opera house. This device was designed by the Hydro Archon, Focalors, and she placed her divinity along with the Hydro Gnosis there. The Oratrice converted the people's faith in justice into Indemnitium, a type of energy that powers Fontaine. If this power, accrued over five centuries, has only been used to sustain Fontainians, it could have lasted for millennia, but it has its purpose. Along with the Chief Justice, this device passed sentences in court, and its sentence has always been crucial. It once falsely accused the Fatui Harbinger, Childe, of connection to the serial dissolution case and declared the Hydro Archon guilty to be punished via the death sentence. Although the Oratrice was used for trials, in truth its main purpose was to kill the God of Justice along with the Divine Throne when the time came. Focalors understood that only power of this magnitude could hope to destroy the Hydro Archon's Divine Throne, shaking the rules established by Celestia and breaking through the institution that is The Seven. After the main trial of the Hydro Archon, the Oratrice was destroyed, and now only the Chief Justice Neuvillette makes final verdicts.

There is a legend in Fontaine that the nation was once ruled by the Hydro Dragon, and every time the dragon cried, the sky became clouded, and rain poured down. To stop the rain, you had to shout into the sky: <color=#ffffffd9>"Hydro dragon, Hydro dragon, don't cry!"</color> Often after tragic court hearings, even on the sunniest day, it suddenly starts raining. This was the case when the former head of Spina di Rosula Callas Caspar, accused of murdering a friend, chose a judicial duel and refused to surrender even on the verge of death.
In accordance with the relevant laws and regulations, and to ensure the best viewing experience for all audience members, no outside food is permitted within the Opera Epiclese. Visitors in violation of the rules will be expelled and punished by the Maison Gardiennage in accordance with the law. Serious offenses will be prosecuted and brought to trial, and the offender will be sentenced in accordance with the law. Moreover, visitors must be properly dressed when entering the Opera Epiclese. Should their attire not meet the prescribed standards, staff members have the right to refuse entrance. Entry is strictly by tickets, which must be booked in advance. The opera house hosts many theatrical performances and legal proceedings. Among the performances was a stage play "The Saga of Aurelius," a trilogy, based upon the epic legend about the hero Aurelius from the fallen empire. The Melusine Philharmonic Orchestra also performed there with excerpts from "Epic of Elynas" and "Ode to Judges," and the magician Lyney performed with the program "Great Magician's Night of Fantasy'' and a new "water tank escape" trick. In addition, the awards ceremony, "The La Verite Prize," takes place in the opera house. This award was organized by The Steambird and is the most prestigious and famous media award in all of Teyvat, is used to recognize and commemorate the greatest individual and collective achievements in media, including newspapers, magazines, journals, and other media fields. Here, the trial of the magician Lyney took place, as well as the trial of serial dissolutions, the case of changing the appearance of Melusine to human, and the case of the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Vautrin, who avenged his Melusine friend, who died due to the fault of people.

One day, the magician's assistant, Lynette, received a threatening letter after the successful opening of the play, "The Lost Puppet." At first, another actress, Gillian, was supposed to play the main role in the play, but suddenly the director put Lynette, who did not have much experience in plays, in her place. Feeling a look of hatred on her, Lynette decided to get to the bottom of what was happening. It turned out that the letter was left by Gillian's younger sister, who blamed Lynette for what was happening. And the look of hatred came from the director of the play: he took Lynette for the role only because of her fame as a magician's assistant. For her sake, he had to rewrite the ending of the play and simplify the role of the main character. When Lynette learned the truth, she persuaded Gillian and other members of the troupe to return to the old script and cast Gillian in the lead role. Since the actress was wearing a mask, no one noticed the substitution at first, and when the identity of the main actress was revealed, everyone was too in love with her performance to talk about the deception.

Not far from the opera house, a Lumidouce Bell, meaning "separation," and a letter left by Melusine Talochard to her dead friend, a Mek named Curve, can be found. Curve was a sentient lie detector whose creator wanted him to learn to understand human lies and to lie himself. His creator died in a legal duel 30 years ago, defending his creation, and later, Talochard found Curve in an evidence room and decided to continue the creator's work. In the end, Curve died defending Talochard, having previously deceived her. In the letter, Talochard reprimanded her friend for lying but expressed her feelings to him.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Still, I don't think Dr. Mosso was right when he said that "a curve is the shortest distance between two people."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>There are definitely some times when you should just shoot your shot straight.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>For example, I miss you."</color>

customize.text: Chemin de L'Espoir

Chemin de L'Espoir is located on the border of the Court of Fontaine and Beryl Region. One day, a scientist from the Fontaine Research Institute, while observing maritime creatures, rescued a Blubberbeast pup from a ray-style clockwork meka that lost control. An examination showed that the pup was much weaker than a normal individual and could not survive in its natural environment. Then the researcher decided to leave it at the observation station not far from Chemin de L'Espoir and named it Berrypuff. When the institute's management withdrew the budget of the scientific group and directed it to "An Innovative Circuit Design Using Clockwork Meka to Simulate the Rock-Paper-Scissors Game and Its Sociological Impact," the scientist had to return.

Since he could not take Berrypuff with him, he left enough food for it to grow up and return to his natural environment. When Paimon saw the researcher's notes, she wanted to see how Berrypuff was doing. It turned out that all the food had been eaten long ago, and the Blubberbeast pup was exhausted. At first, it was timid about the treat, but in the end, it ate it greedily. After some time of regular feeding and helping other animals, Berrypuff grew up and was able to go live with his friends.
Annapausis is located on one side of the location. One day, a little Oceanid named Ann's friends were in trouble, and she went from Annapausis to Chemin de L'Espoir for help. The Traveler and Paimon, who were passing by, responded to her request and went to Annapausis to save her friends.

customize.text: Annapausis

The gentle breeze winds through the flowery meadows in Mont Esus, setting the creaking arms of windmills to turn lazily. The peaceful and relaxed atmosphere here causes people to naturally find themselves dwelling on their most pleasant memories. Some foothills of Mont Esus by the sea close to the Palais Mermonia. Visitors can feel the gentle breeze as they step onto the vast flower fields. According to ancient records, a magnificent palace was once built here. Named after the flowers, it sought to sing praises of love and to nurture abandoned orphans above the countless waters. Though the high tower of old no longer graces this land, the flowers remain as fragrant as ever.

Before the Cataclysm 500 years ago, Annapausis was the site of the Narzissenkreuz Institute, Fontaine's orphanage. After the fall of Remuria, the Fontainian Government decided to incorporate the Institute for raising orphans and the children of criminals into the public welfare system. In honor of the remains of the previous civilization, on the site on which the institute was located, it received the name the Narzissenkreuz Institute. As a token of gratitude to the Hydro Archon Egeria, the gentle Oceanid Lyris was placed at the head of the Institute. More than 500 years ago, Basil Elton, who grew up in the orphanage herself, became the Vice Director of the Narzissenkreuz Institute. Although sunlight never reached the Institute, it was always warm and bustling with life.

Basil told the children stories about Princess Lyris and the evil dragon Narcissus. During the Cataclysm, the Narzissenkreuz Institute was abandoned and ceased to exist. Basil Elton led the fleet of the Fontaine Armada and went to fight the creatures of the Abyss, and Lyris never understood the connection between the Cataclysm and the disappearance of the students, so she was later seen wandering near the abandoned institute. Later she joined the radical organization, the Narzissenkreuz Ordo. Many students, including Mary-Ann Guillotin, became members of the Marechaussee Phantom or the Special Patrol, and others began to travel around the world.

During the battle between agents of the Marechaussee Phantom and members of the Narzissenkreuz Ordo, among whom was Lyris and Mary-Ann Guillotin, an explosion occurred. Mary-Ann Guillotin was on the verge of death, and Lyris hugged her, merging their consciousnesses together. From this merge, a new oceanid, Mary-Ann, was born. She was no longer Mary-Ann Guillotin nor Lyris. Wanting to remain in past memories, Mary-Ann created "The Real Annapausis," willingly becoming its captive. She created a fairy-tale house for herself, where she lived in her dreams.

One day, Mary-Ann was able to create another oceanid, Ann, after seeing her in a dream. Since Ann was part of Mary-Ann, she received part of the memories of Lyris and Mary-Ann Guillotin. Her main memory was the tale about the dragon Narcissus, which Basil Elton told to the children in the orphanage. Ann believed that her goal was to save Princess Lyris from the fairy tale, who she thought Mary-Ann was.

Oceanid Ann, with the help of the Traveler and Paimon, went to Annapausis to save her friends and Princess Lyris from the dragon sleeping on the institute building. To enable Ann and the Traveler to get to the princess's castle, Ann's friends had to sacrifice themselves and merge together. When Ann and the Traveler walked through the endless labyrinth and found the Holy Blade of Narzissenkreuz, they discovered a book of fairy tales, through which they entered "The Real Annapausis." It turned out that Mary-Ann was the princess for all this time, and she did not want to return to reality. She told Ann to live her life and do what she wanted, and then kicked them out of "The Real Annapausis," destroying the portal in the book through which they got there. When Ann discovered the truth about her and Mary-Ann's origins, she wanted to separate the identities of Oceanid Lyris and Mary-Ann Guillotin, but Mary-Ann accepted her past and decided to leave her prison.

customize.text: Institute of Natural Philosophy

The old building of the Institute of Natural Philosophy is located near Chemin de L'Espoir. It was once a thriving research facility but now lies in ruin beneath the waters of Fontaine. The director of the institute was Dwight Lasker, an old friend of Emanuel Guillotin, Karl Ingold, and Basil Elton, with whom he grew up in an orphanage. After the Cataclysm that occurred 500 years ago, an energy crisis arose in Fontaine, so the main focus was the search for new energy sources. Significant efforts were made to transport Primal Constructs to the Institute for thorough examination due to the noticeable technological gap between the Primal Constructs found in the ruins of Sumeru's desert, and the clockwork machines prevalent during this era. Two young prodigies of the Institute, Alain Guillotin and Rene, used the characteristics of Ousia and Pneuma to construct a new kinetic core which eventually led to the first controlled annihilation reaction.

After annihilation reactions were proven to be successful, research shifted to Kinematics. The experiments that took place here involved Khaenri'ahn machines, such as Ruin Graders, and were noted to be so dangerous an emergency damage control strategy was implemented for safety. Alain's experiments into machines were perceived by other researchers as an intention to create a mechanical dog as proof of his accomplishments in Kinematics and material science. Alain's assistant had suggested creating such a thinking machine, a thinking Kamera to be precise, so that it would take photos of those precious to Alain while he was busy. Alain found using a thinking Kamera for this reason to be pointless, but he found such a machine useful for security and surveillance applications. Seymour, Prototype 4ACV07, was the thinking machine Alain created for Mary-Ann Guillotin and takes the form of a mechanical dog. Seymour was created by Alain to protect his adoptive sister Mary-Ann and was made with the most advanced optics from the Fontaine Institute of Natural Philosophy.

While Alain and other researchers focused on Kinematics, Rene and Jakob Ingold, who was a child at this time, had different research directions and they applied for a research lab of their own. Rene and Jakob eventually obtained their own lab, and they limited access to it due to the dangerous nature of their research. Rene acquired something powerful to research that appeared after the disaster, which was very dangerous for most people, but Jakob felt his constitution became "better" after being exposed to it. This research eventually led to an experiment on Carter, albeit in an attempt to save his life, which had disastrous effects on him.

At the end of the Central Quartier of the Institute, the gathering place of an esoteric society known as the Narzissenkreuz Ordo can be found using an indecipherable book. This book leads to the Tower of Ipsissimus in the Morte Region. Although Rene found it quite sad that people from an Institute of Natural Philosophy have somewhat turned into his believers, he established the Narzissenkreuz Ordo within the Institute to give his followers a sense of belonging. The Ordo did not go unnoticed among the leaders of the Institute, but as there was no evidence of aggression or any invasive nature, the case was not pursued through official investigative channels. After the Institute disbanded, some of its former members joined the Narzissenkreuz Ordo at Mr. Ingold's invitation. Much of the continued research focused on the ancient civilization of Remuria. This led to the uncovering of an ancient copy of an unknown document within the Institute of Natural Philosophy containing Remurian characters that seemed to be some form of phonography. This ultimately aided in the decipherment of unknown esoteric Remurian documents.

One day, the Traveler and Paimon met Virgil from Spina di Rosula in the Court of Fontaine, and he asked them to help find the vault of the secret society "Liliacruses Forum." He wanted to use everything they found against the other members of the organization, Sonny and Luka. When Virgil realized that the so-called Liliacruses Forum was actually the Institute of Natural Philosophy, he attempted to get rid of the Traveler and Paimon in order to take their Mora. After escaping from the invincible Ruin Guard, the Traveler and Paimon met Sonny and his partner Luka, who were looking for Virgil. Together, they discovered a shipment of illegal Sinthe that Virgil and his henchmen were trying to sell. After a "very long and serious conversation," Virgil was never seen again.

customize.text: Salacia Plain

At the bottom of the sea plateau lies the wreckage of Fontaine's great white fleet. In the past, it traversed the seas and was Fontaine's supreme pride and glory. The First Hydro Archon, Egeria, blessed people with the authority and wish to conquer all waters of the world. However, that lofty ambition was insufficient to overcome the laws of fate, and the fleet was destroyed during the Cataclysm in the fight against the creature from the Abyss, Elynas. To this day, on the brass masts are inscribed the words: <color=#ffffffd9>"I have conquered the waters of the four seas."</color>

The All-Devouring Narwhal, that once devoured the birthing waters of the planet, has departed without a single trace, but those in the know will forever live, surely, in the terrifying shadow of that omen of the end. At the bottom of Salacia Plain, a single shard of shattered spacetime remains, and through it, one may perhaps be able to witness that titanic creature once more.

On Salacia Plain, a base for Sinthe production, a drug created from the diluted water of the Primordial Sea, is located. Once, there was a source of the Primordial Sea, which was discovered by the adventurers Vacher and Vigneire. Vigneire, touching the water, dissolved before the eyes of her beloved. He wanted to follow her, but he was not a native of Fontaine, and the water of the Primordial Sea had no effect on him. Out of grief, Vacher began to look for ways to bring Vigneire back. One day he found the notes of Jakob Ingold, a member of the Narzissenkreuz Ordo, who had conducted experiments using the water of the Primordial Sea many years ago, and decided to use this research in his experiments. Vacher began kidnapping Fontainian women the same age as Vigneire in an attempt to revive his beloved. To remain above suspicion, Vacher decided to get rid of his old identity and came up with a story about a businessman Marcel who had just arrived in Fontaine. He found the name Marcel in Vigneire's diary, where she chose names for her and Vacher's children.

During his research, Marcel noticed that a small amount of Primordial Sea water, diluted in ordinary water, is not lethal even for the inhabitants of Fontaine, but has intoxicating properties. Marcel named this drink Sinthe and started an underground business producing it. This drink could excite your mood and produce many pleasant hallucinations. With long-term use of Sinthe, many side effects occur, including a loss of the ability to focus or control one's emotions. Upon withdrawal, the person experienced flashes of paranoia and anxiety while lacking the energy to do anything. Marcel became the head of the Confrerie of Cabriere, a guild in Poisson. In the beginning, they were only reselling some daily goods, but later they became one of the richest guilds around with a lot of business connections in the city.

Due to the side effects of long-term use of Sinthe, three years ago, the head of Poisson, Callas Caspar, banned its distribution in Poisson and began an investigation. He soon saw a connection between Sinthe and serial dissolutions. Due to a fatal illness, he knew that he would not be able to complete the investigation, so he conveyed information about the location of Marcel's base to his butler, Melus. Three years later, Callas's daughter, Navia, continued her father's work. According to information from Melus, the Traveler and Paimon discovered the base and evidence, thanks to which they were able to prove Marcel's guilt. After this, all shipments of Sinthe were destroyed by the Maison Gardiennage.

customize.text: Thalatta Submarine Canyon

Thalatta Submarine Canyon lies on the border between the Court of Fontaine and Liffey Regions. Since the Fortress of Meropide, an underwater prison, is located nearby, all non-Maison Gestion approved activities are prohibited in the canyon. The Callas aquabus line used to pass through above the canyon, connecting the Court of Fontaine and the Fontaine Research Institute, but the recent explosion of the Central Laboratory destroyed the route.

Near the underwater canyon, the director of the Fishing Association, Delaroche, resides. Even though she is the director, she has not been able to catch a single fish. Previously, she was an ordinary employee of the Fontaine Research Institute, responsible for purchasing materials, negotiating with suppliers, and bringing down prices, but most of the time, just waiting for the suppliers to respond. While waiting, she wandered the city streets until she met new friends from the Fishing Association, and they introduced her to the joy of fishing. Delaroche fell in love with this activity, and her life took on new meaning. In gratitude, she supplied the fishermen with various equipment from the Institute, which helped them get a large catch. Since Delaroche had established connections with various merchants and was always ready to come to the rescue, everyone decided to elect her as the head of the Association. But even when she was at her post, she could not catch a single fry. It turned out that Delaroche uses bait that dissolves in water. When the Traveler helped her with bait, she decided to use baits that were too hard for the fish to swallow. As a result, the Traveler and Paimon left her a recipe for a simple and effective bait as a gift in the hope that now the head of the Association will learn to fish. One day Delaroche met the Melusine Iara and taught her fishing techniques. Due to the specifics of Delaroche's skills, Iara was unable to catch a fish, so she decided to place a ball octopus in her pond and practice on it.

On land near the canyon, a secret laboratory for the production of Imitation Sinthe, a new drug that appeared after Sinthe disappeared from the market, was located. Pierre, a researcher from the Fontaine Research Institute, prepared drugs in the laboratory, placed them in special impenetrable bags, and then transported them in barrels across the river. Thanks to the actions of the commander of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Chevreuse, as well as the magician Lynette, the case of Imitation Sinthe was solved.

On the foothills of Mount Esus, there are ruins left over from the ancient civilization of Remuria. In distant times, when the first Hydro Archon had not yet returned from confinement, another God King, Remus, dreamed of building a prosperous empire out of harmonious music atop the waves. But the great ambition of building a utopia failed to come to fruition, and the arrogance of humanity sank into their depths along with their pride. The golden music is long silent, only the cold music of the tides still echoes upon the remains of their grand altars.
Near these ruins, the artist Salsa once painted a landscape, but her view was obstructed by structures created by adventurers. Therefore, Salsa decided to fight the designs and created the "Alliance of Artists to Overthrow the Evil Organization and Protect the Future of Fontaine." It turned out that all these structures were installed by an adventurer and installation artist, Ubu. Since Salsa did not appreciate his innovative approach to art, she moved all of his installations to fit into the landscape. The two artists could not agree on whose work could be called art, so Ubu left, defeated and promising to become a great artist.

Further along Mont Esus, beyond the Court of Fontaine, a small village is located. Earnshaw lives here with his daughter's dogs: Brave, Princess, and Prince. Earnshaw's daughter Agnes was a freedom-loving woman and left her father. He expected him to return, so he didn't even read the letters she sent him. It turned out that Agnes ended up in the Fortress of Meropide, where she gave birth to her daughter, Lanoire. She was beautiful, like a small flower emerging from a crack in a rock and grew persistently and selflessly even where there was neither sun nor rain. After some time, Agnes fell ill and died in the fortress, without having time to prepare documents for her daughter. With the help of Lanoire's friend, Caterpillar, the guard Estienne, the Traveler, and Paimon, Lanoire escaped from the Fortress of Meropide and was reunited with her grandfather. When Caterpillar, whose real form is a hilichurl, decided to visit Lanoire for her birthday, Earnshaw feared for his granddaughter and called the Gardes for help. Since Caterpillar had lost the ability to transform into a human, he said goodbye to Lanoire, told her to never talk to anyone who looked like him and disappeared.

In the same village lived the sick mother of a researcher from the Fontaine Research Institute, Potton. Potton was ugly, and no one wanted to communicate or cooperate with him. Only criminals entered into an agreement with him. During his research, Potton created a face-changing agent, the main component of which was the liquid remaining from the Fontainians dissolved by the Primordial Sea. Potton changed his appearance and became Rawat. He first spent all his money on treating his mother, but nothing helped, and she could not even recognize her son after the change. Rawat decided not to miss the opportunity and earn more, and the main component of the product was provided to him by the head of the Confrerie of Cabriere, Marcel, who was behind the production of Sinthe and the serial dissolution of women. When Rawat's mother was dying, he decided to change his appearance to his original one for the last time to say goodbye to her, but his mother had already lost her sight and did not recognize him even by touch.
